case_name: Sayeed-ur-Rahman v. Managing Committee of Araria Higher Secondary School

facts.text: This is a Civil Appeal No. 1222 of 1967 by special leave.

facts.text: Appeal directed against Patna High Court order dated September 3, 1965 dismissing appellant's writ petition in M.J. Case No. 1257 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 3, 1965 of the Patna High Court in M. J. Case No. 1257 of 1964. P. Singh for the appellant.

issues.text: Whether the President of the Board of Secondary Education could modify the earlier order dated April 22, 1960 without giving to the petitioner an adequate opportunity of being heard

issues.text: Whether principles of natural justice require the President to afford adequate opportunity of hearing before reconsidering the order dated April 22, 1960

anchor.surface_text: This rule embodies the principle of natural justice requiring the appellate authority to hear the parties. The order dated April 22, 1960 must have, therefore, been made after hearing both sides as provided by this rule. There is no express provision for review

arguments.claim: High Court erred in declining relief against review order merely because original order invalid per precedent; only review challenged

anchor.surface_text: Before us on behalf of the appellant it was strenuously contended that the appellant had approached the High Court with his grievance only against the order made by the President of the Board reviewing his earlier order dated April 22, 1960 without hearing the appellant and that being the only relief claimed by him, if the said order of review was unconstitutional having been made to the appellants prejudice without affording him an adequate opportunity of being heard then the High Court could not decline him the relief of declaring it to be invalid, on the sole ground that the earlier order which was not challenged by the petitioner in those proceedings and had not been got quashed by the Managing Committee in any appropriate proceedings being contrary to law on the basis of Liladhar Jha supra , it would be somewhat academic to declare as invalid the review order impugned by the appellant before that Court.

arguments.claim: Impugned order justified on reasons stated by High Court; no challenge to Liladhar Jha

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the respondents Shri S. C. Agarwal appearing for the State of Bihar and the Board of Secondary Education, did not challenge the view taken by the Patna High Court in the case of Liladhar Jha supra . He tried to justify the impugned order only on the reasons stated by the High Court.

arguments.claim: High Court should have declared President's orders dated February 25, 1961 and January 18, 1964 invalid for lack of hearing

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion on the facts and circumstances of this case it was incumbent on the High Court to declare as invalid, the order of the President of the Board of Secondary Education dated February 25, 1961 reviewing the earlier order dated April 22, 1960, without affording to the appellant any opportunity of being heard, ,and also his order dated January 18, 1964.

arguments.claim: Denying relief on academic grounds unfair and unjust; MC may still consider review orders operative

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had approached the High Court with a grievance against that order and the order dated April 22, 1960, which was in his favour, was advisedly not challenged by him. To decline to the appellant the relief claimed by him to which, according to the High Courts own reasoning, he was without doubt entitled, on the mere ground that it would be academic to do so, seems to us to be highly unfair and unjust to the appellant, because. as represented before us the Managing Committee might well take a different view and feel that the orders passed by the President of the Board of Secondary

arguments.claim: Managing Committee expected to obey Board directions under r.18 and s.5 Bihar High Schools Act

anchor.surface_text: Under r. 18 and S. 5 of the Bihar High Schools Control and Regulation of Administration Act Bihar Act XIII , 1960 the Managing Committee is expected to obey the directions of the Board.

arguments.claim: Board orders final under s.6 Bihar High Schools Act

anchor.surface_text: It may also be pointed out that under S. 6 of the above Act orders of the Board are final.

arguments.claim: r.17 embodies natural justice requiring hearing; applies to reconsideration even without express review power

anchor.surface_text: Rule 17 reads The appeal of the person concerned shall be heard by the President of the Board of Secondary Education or any member of the Board of Secondary Education duly nominated by the President or any officer ordinarily not below the rank of Inspector of Schools.

arguments.claim: Fundamental unwritten right to hearing in quasi-judicial decisions on controversial issues

anchor.surface_text: We are, however, clear that if the order dated April 22, 1960 is to be reconsidered then the appellant must be afforded adequate opportunity of hearing and presenting his case. This unwritten right of hearing is fundamental to a just decision by any authority which decides a controversial issue affecting the rights of the rival contestants.

holdings.text: It was incumbent on the High Court to declare as invalid the order of the President dated February 25, 1961 and the order dated January 18, 1964 as they were made without affording the appellant any opportunity of being heard.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion on the facts and circumstances of this case it was incumbent on the High Court to declare as invalid, the order of the President of the Board of Secondary Education dated February 25, 1961 reviewing the earlier order dated April 22, 1960, without affording

holdings.reasoning_summary: Orders adversely affected appellant's rights in quasi-judicial proceedings without hearing, violating audi alteram partem; High Court wrongly deemed issue academic.

holdings.text: The President could not modify the order dated April 22, 1960 without giving the appellant an adequate opportunity of being heard; principles of natural justice require hearing before reconsideration even absent express review power.

anchor.surface_text: This rule embodies the principle of natural justice requiring the appellate authority to hear the parties. The order dated April 22, 1960 must have, therefore, been made after hearing both sides as provided by this rule. There is no express provision for review

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 17 embodies natural justice for appeals; unwritten right to hearing fundamental for quasi-judicial authorities deciding controversial issues affecting rights.

holdings.text: Appeal allowed; impugned High Court order, President's orders dated February 25, 1961 and January 18, 1964 set aside; parties relegated to stage prior to February 25, 1961 with direction for hearing if President reconsiders April 22, 1960 order.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the only just and fair order to be made in these proceedings is to allow this appeal, set aside the impugned order of the the Court as also the order made by the President of the Board of Secondary Eduaction dated February 25, 1961  reviewing his earlier order dated April 22, 1960  along with the subsequent order

holdings.reasoning_summary: To provide relief against invalid orders and ensure fair reconsideration if pursued.

holdings.text: Managing Committee bound to obey Board directions under r.18 and s.5 Bihar High Schools Act 1960; Board orders final under s.6.

anchor.surface_text: Under r. 18 and S. 5 of the Bihar High Schools  Control and Regulation of Administration  Act  Bihar Act XIII , 1960 the Managing Committee is expected to obey the directions of the Board. It may also be pointed out that under S. 6 of the above Act orders of the Board are final.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules and Act impose obligation on Managing Committee to comply until set aside, justifying quashing invalid orders to enable payment.

holdings.text: Appellant entitled to costs from contesting respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is entitled to his costs from the contesting respondents.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Standard order on success in appeal.
